awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Weaning practices, subsistence strategies, and skeletal growth and development
awd_abstract_narration:
The human skeleton is capable of plastic responses to biomechanical pressures, including those associated with chewing. This doctoral dissertation project examines relationships between dietary patterns and skeletal characteristics through analysis of pre-industrial populations with various weaning and subsistence practices. The research advances insights about biocultural factors that may influence skeletal growth and development in our species, including factors affecting dental alignment and function.  The project fosters graduate student training of a female scientist, dissemination of findings including to clinical audiences, science education and curriculum development for students, and public science communication through popular science outlets. 

While researchers have found differences in face and jaw shape with differing subsistence strategies, the effects of weaning practices and the biomechanical effects of suckling are not well understood. Additionally, modern infant behavior such as thumb-sucking, bottle-feeding and early termination of breastfeeding are implicated in the rise of dental malocclusions, suggesting that shifts in weaning practices that are thought to have occurred with the advent of farming may be partially responsible for the increase in modern dental occlusion problems. This project investigates associations between facial morphology, weaning practices, and subsistence strategies, using cranial and mandibular 3D scan data. The project also seeks to assess the association between weaning/subsistence behavior and dental occlusion patterns by quantifying dental occlusion using modern orthodontic criteria.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
The purpose of this research was to investigate the potential biomechanical impacts of variable, culturally informed weaning practices on the development of the human skull and the ultimate relationship between craniomandibular morphology and dental occlusal class. Moreover, it revisits previous research on the association between craniomandibular morphology and patterns of subsistence (e.g., hunter-gatherer versus agriculturalist) with a unique dataset. While it is broadly accepted that diet can impact the development of face shape, few studies have been conducted on globally and temporally diverse datasets and none have assessed the potential importance of suckling behaviors. This despite the implications of modern infant behaviors, such as early termination of weaning, for the rise of more frequent and severe malocclusions in modern populations. This research begins to examine these possibilities by aggregating a unique dataset, collating 3D scans and photos, dental occlusal classes, and published ethnographic materials and isotopic studies.

The populations included in the resulting dataset are globally and temporally distributed, representing a wide range of human dietary and infant feeding behaviors. It is composed of twelve populations originating from North and South America, Europe, East Asia and North Africa and includes subsistence strategies from hunting and gathering to transitional and intensive agricultural. The weaning behaviors represented are similarly diverse with cultural averages ranging from 2 to 4 years of age. Subsistence strategies and weaning practices were determined for each population through an aggregation of published ethnographies and isotopic studies. Utilizing human remains from previously excavated archaeological sites, the crania and mandibles of individuals from each population were examined to determine dental occlusal class; then each was photographed and scanned in order to generate 3D images. Approximately 1,100 3D scans and 10,000 photos were collected for this research for a sample of 477 individuals.

The 3D scans will be processed and landmarked in order to quantify differences in face shape and size. Differences in craniomandibular morphology and dental occlusal class will be analyzed in association with behavior (i.e., subsistence and weaning) to determine if there is a possible relationship. Data processing and analysis is currently ongoing. However, preliminary results of 2D morphometric data affirm that there exists a statistically significant relationship between subsistence practices and cranial morphology. Furthermore, there are confounding effects on face shape and size arising from environmental adaptations and sexual dimorphism. Once data analysis is complete (by the end of 2023), results will be written up in spring 2024 and disseminated to key stakeholders and the scientific community through presentations at professional conferences, publication of articles in scientific journals, communication of results in popular science outlets, and organization of outreach events with institutions involved in the production of this research.

While additional outreach activities are forthcoming, this research project has already created a training opportunity for a female minority student. Through mentorship, she planned, executed, and reported the results of her work in a senior honors thesis. The technological aspect of this research and its potential implications for clinical research have already been shared with a broader public audience. In collaboration with a museum curatorial staff, this project was highlighted in the internal newsletter of the collaborating institution. Finally, visual representations of the data collected during the course of this research, e.g., 3D scans, were assembled and stylized for submission in a public display at the Buffalo Museum of Science in April 2023 as part of the public reception for the inaugural Art in Research competition.


Last Modified: 07/27/2023
Modified by: Noreen Von Cramon-Taubadel
